183705787.review:
Times like these make me wish Steam had a mixed review option. Because, in this case, I would give mixed review. The main reason I am giving a negative review is because, despite having alot of positive experiences with the game, I am currently feeling negative towards it. Stress and tedium to be precise.

The thing is that, at the beginning, I really wanted to like this game. I really did. But it got really very grind heavy towards the end and eventually it felt like a chore to play. As you max out your base and gain money more and more easily the only thing that caps out is the level at which your heroes are fed in. In the late game, when you have little sources and very many sinks of said heroes, it can feel very repetitive  having to make essentially no progress by leveling up your heroes on mid to low level quests. And there's always the chance you will lose these heroes at vary degrees of your own fault; Then you are deprived of, if not your whole team, then a key member, which means you lack a congruent group to do the high level quests - Which you absolutely do need later in the game. It really felt like I was running in circles the whole time and got to the point where it kind of felt like a chore to play. If i wanted that feeling I would clock in a nine to five, and atleast then I would be making money.

It is the sort of pit fall alot of rogue-likes,and even some rogue-lites ,fail to escape. You reach a point eventually where no gains are being made, and simultaneously nothing new is being added. And I am refering quite late into the game. I mean like week 150 onwards. 

Overall, I kind of have a love hate relationship with this game. I liked it at the beginning, and I still want to like it. it's kind of like a toxic relationship. You want to stay to try and make things work again, desperate for that feeling of better times. But also, You know you should leave because it isn't worth the stress fighting for unrealised gains. I am sure i will revisit Darkest Dungeon someday, and gain a more positive view, but for now I am hanging up. if you haven't purchased the game and are reading this, don't be dissuaded. Just know what you are getting into.

183645920.review:
This game is basically a more feature-filled version of labyrinth-mode Epic 7, but reworked in such a way that it doesn't have / need microtransactions. Biggest difference is unit perma-death and unit psychology, especially stress (which can make units erratic). Units can also pick up all sorts of crazy diseases from unworldly enemies, ranging from rabies to syphilis (not exaggerating, it's literally a thing). Gear grind due to RNG doesn't exist in this game, but gear is tied to units, which balances things.

Has excellent audio design and a beautifully-narrated story.

On the negative side, I feel the trinkets aren't always very well thought out and mostly favour tanks, though they're still better than Epic 7's equivalent (artefacts). Also, this game desperately needs team loadouts, but given the age of the game this is unlikely to happen. And there are no mods for this (that I could find).

Be prepared to lose units. They're like socks in this game; you wear them, tear holes in them, and then watch them succumb to the will of a siren (and then die) because you're a useless manager. It's great. I need more socks.

183573552.review: This game turned me into a monster. It's borderline a psychological horror - not in the sense that the game is psychologically upsetting, but rather that it tests the resolve of the player. I started this game, as I do most, clinging to my morals. Making sure everyone's cared for and taking an empathetic approach. But this game demands sacrifice. By the end of it, I had driven people to suicide, pardoned murder, abandoned useless people to die, and caused irreversible psychological trauma to the soldiers I sent in. By the end of my grueling campaign I had marched 61 men and women to their deaths. The last death in particular I'll never forget. She was the only one who didn't want to go, but I chose her to ensure the safety of the mission above all. Throughout the game, you gradually learn of the horrific deeds your ancestor performed in their search for truth. By the end of it, you're one and the same.

Hi, 
hier meine Meinung zum Spiel:
Ich hatte Darkest Dungeon seit Jahren auf meiner Wunschliste, war mir aber nie ganz sicher, ob es was für mich ist. Ich habe zuvor noch nie roque-like Spiele gespielt. Aber schließlich war es vor ein paar Wochen im Angebot und ich habe zugeschlagen.
Mein Fazit ist gemischt. Es ist durchaus interessant und wenn man speziell noch nie derartige Spiele hatte, dann ist die Anfangszeit spannend und macht wahnsinnig Spaß. Aber leider nutzt sich der Spielspaß sehr schnell ab und Ernüchterung kehrt ein. Das Spiel wird bereits ab 20-25 Spielstunden sehr wiederholend und damit langweilig. Ich habe noch 20 Stunden weitergespielt ohne das es großartig Spaß gemacht hätte, aber habe dann mitten im Spiel aufgehört.
Das Spiel hat definitv seinen Reiz, nutzt sich aber sehr schnell ab und zum Kampf im Spiel kommt auch sehr schnell der Kampf mit einem selbst, ob man wirklich weiterspielen möchte. Ich konnte irgendwann nicht mehr weiter.

Zu einem günstigen Preis kann man sich das Spiel holen, aber es hat kaum Durch- und Wiederspielpotential, da schnell langweilig. Nur für Fans des Genres zu empfehlen.
------------ 
Here's my opinion about the game:
I've had Darkest Dungeon on my wish list for years, but was never quite sure if it was for me. I've never played roque-like games before. But finally it was on sale a few weeks ago and I snapped it up.
My conclusion is mixed. It's quite interesting and especially if you've never had games like this before, then the early days are exciting and a lot of fun. But unfortunately the fun of the game wears out very quickly and disillusionment sets in. The game becomes very repetitive and therefore boring after 20-25 hours of play. I continued playing for another 20 hours without having much fun, but then stopped in the middle of the game.
The game definitely has its charm, but it wears out very quickly and the fight in the game quickly turns into a fight with yourself as to whether you really want to continue playing. At some point I couldn't go any further.

You can get the game at a reasonable price, but it has little potential to be played through or replayed as it quickly becomes boring. Only recommended for fans of the genre.

183533110.review:
Not going to lie, it was great fun at first.  Then I get to the point where my characters are maxed out but are no match for the next boss I had to fight (let alone the one after it).  I don't care that there's a disclaimer at the beginning about how much the game expects from you and that a lot of your characters are going to die; basic game design dictates that a game needs to be fun.  When fun is drained away by overwhelming and unnecessary "challenge" (i.e. glaring balance issues) where you are throwing waves of maxed out characters at the problem and still watching them *almost* succeed, it becomes a chore to play.  I can find that type of frustration elsewhere in life and don't really need, or want, it in my down time.

Love the mechanics.  Has a great story line and production.  Hopefully they eased up in the sequel.  Will probably play this some more later, but at this point, I think I would rather go get my sack waxed.
